hobby.message: Antique typewriter giving you trouble again?
Urban exploring with that homebrew again?
Origami's still better than meds, huh?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Still turning, at least on this side. Times are odd, yes.
I keep busy restoring old typewriters. Simple work, doesn't mind chaos.
Blackout took me off the keys last night. Happens again, I’ll adapt.
City’s noisy, but the right corners are still quiet.
I restore antique typewriters to pass the time. Reliable, unlike the grid lately.
Power cuts are common now—had to fix a ribbon by candlelight.
Things change, but old machines wait patiently.
Still spinning, just off balance, I’d say.
I spend evenings working on antique typewriters. Predictable rhythm—less so lately.
Blackouts disrupted my latest repair session. Not uncommon in my zone.
Strange hearing laughter from the street while I worked by candlelight.
Seems people are adjusting faster than the circuits.
Everything’s unsettled, but I find steadiness fixing old typewriters.
My flat’s full of Underwoods and Remingtons—each with a history longer than the Council’s.
Last week, blackout caught me mid-repair. Ended up writing notes by hand.
Funny, felt more honest to put ink on paper again.
Saw neighbors organizing during the outage—scoreless types running their own clinic.
Power cuts used to be rare, now they’re habit in my district.
Spinning, but it’s a different world out there now. Used to be predictable.
You know, I spent half my career shepherding Council schedules—now I restore antique typewriters.
Started before the BCI. Still prefer them to digital systems, honestly.
Most nights, I record memories on a 1920s Underwood. Outages make it an exercise in patience.
During the latest blackout, I heard kids outside reading poetry out loud—scoreless, ignoring the index.
Those power cuts used to feel like punishment. Now, they’re a reason to slow down.
My journals are safer on paper. Learned that lesson after all these leaks.
Sometimes I think: maybe these old keys will outlast the BCI itself.
hobby_answer: Yes, the carriage finally moves. Routine work. Nothing much to tell.
Harder to find parts—those markets get emptier each week.
Strange times, Alex. Power’s off more often these days.
Can’t fix much when city’s dark. Slows me down.
That’s all, really.
Managed to get it working, after a fashion.
Finding replacement ribbons lately? Entire stalls gone overnight.
Grid issues last night—whole block without power again.
Everyone’s distracted. Fewer crowds at the old repair shops.
Suppose hobbies aren’t a priority when districts turn scoreless.
Still, a working typewriter clears the mind.
Yes, fixed it—stuck keys, classic wear. Not too difficult.
Almost gave up—couldn’t source a new spring anywhere nearby.
Power outage made me pause halfway. No warning at all these days.
Used a lantern to finish. Reminded me of my first repairs.
It’s odd: people outside were busy, not worried, even cheerful.
Scoreless clinics, little gatherings. Times really are shifting.
Feels like machinery belongs to another era now.
It’s running smooth now. The 'E' and 'T' were stubborn—I took my time.
Honestly, finding repair parts is half the battle. Markets just don’t run like they used to.
Lights went out, whole street in darkness, so I finished repair by lamplight.
Strange comfort in doing it the old way—felt private, almost secret.
Heard neighbors laughing, heading to that scoreless-run clinic on Gora Street.
Folks are less tense, talking openly without worrying about BCI for once.
Guess even hobbies change when a city’s in revolt.
I keep writing my notes by hand—safer than trusting the grid now.
Oh, it’s finally working—mechanical fixes help occupy my hands when the world frays.
I started with typewriters decades ago, when words meant paper and signatures.
Funny—outage hit midway. Power’s unreliable since all those BCI meltdowns.
No notification, no one calling it in—old support lines are just ghosts now.
Finished by candlelight, listening to neighbors wonder if we’d lost the system for good.
Scoreless clinics are popping up—people tending to their own, without any oversight.
The repair markets are changing hands too—ex-officials trading spare parts quietly.
Typewriting almost feels rebellious now, keeping a record nobody else can surveil.
These days I don’t mind the hush. It’s honest work, and safer than most of my habits.
